text:
Have you ever heard of the old saying, birds of a feather flock together?


Many social and economic phenomena are interconnected, as individuals and institutions are embedded within complex networks that shape behaviors, opportunities, and outcomes.For example, below we show a friendship network of UK academics in an anonymous faculty. It consists of 81 vertices (individuals) and 817 directed and weighted connections. The school affiliation of each individual is stored as a vertex attribute. This dataset serves as a precursor for co-authorship networks, and thus innovation clusters. 
Network, whether social relationships, trade, or financial systems‚Äîserve as conduits for information, influence, and resources. Understanding these intricate connections is crucial for analyzing the spread of ideas, economic inequality, and the dynamics of cooperation and competition within society. 
NECF4P is an online course on Network Science, and in particular its application to the novel field of Economic Complexity to study trade and innovation networks and global value chains.


Code
library(igraph)
library(igraphdata)
data("UKfaculty")

uklay <- layout_nicely(UKfaculty)
E(UKfaculty)$intensity <-rnorm(gsize(UKfaculty), mean = 5, sd = 3) # friendship weight
#clusters of edge types: we want to see what type of relationships exist in our sample
E(UKfaculty)$relation <- sample(c("friendship", "colleagues", "romance", "academic_rivals"), size = gsize(UKfaculty), replace=T)

#setting colors to Group attribute
colores <- c("orange", "tomato", "royalblue", "pink") 
V(UKfaculty)$color <- colores[V(UKfaculty)$Group]
#by doing this before the plot, you no longer have to specify vertex color
#also, you will notice in the plot that the order in which you set the colors
#corresponds to the ascending order of the $Group attribute

plot(UKfaculty,
     edge.arrow.size=.04, 
     main='UK faculty network',
     vertex.size=8,
     vertex.frame.color="gray",
     #vertex.label.color="black",
     #vertex.label.cex=0.8,
     #vertex.label.dist=0.1,
     #edge.curved=0.2
     )

title: How to communicate research through policy briefs
text: From research to impact: this policy brief toolkit will help you gain the skills to effectively communicate your research findings to policy audiences.

About us
The Capacity Development Office (CDO) of UNU-MERIT provides career-enhancing training for policymakers and practitioners. Our programmes are designed to help participants influence and implement policy related to the UN‚Äôs Sustainable Development Goals.
Our purpose as a university and UN think tank is to offer unique learning and training opportunities not only to students but also to everyone looking to address contemporary and future sustainable development challenges, expand their knowledge and networks, and achieve personal and professional growth.
Our participants come from across the world and backgrounds including government, civil society, academia, NGOs, international organisations and the UN itself. To allow work activities and educational programmes to be undertaken simultaneously, courses and trainings are offered in-person, online and with a blend of both approaches.
Our programmes cover a wide range of topics and societal issues. Often developed in collaboration with UNU-MERIT‚Äôs Research Units and external partners, they translate and tailor academic knowledge for professional uptake in order to have true impact.
Besides our free learning materials, which you can find in this website, we also offer a range of paid options, such as:  



Personal tutor to guide you through the free materials and resources


Personalized workshops or in-depth learning content development


Paid courses on various topics.

title: ML4PP: Machine Learning for Public Policies
text:
Welcome!



We have hosted the Machine Learning for Public Policies course on a separate website for your convenience. The course was once live with regular meetings and tutors. Now, the course is asynchronous. All videos, reproduction scripts, and data materials remain online for you to follow at your own pace.






Note



If you would like to hire a private tutor to guide you through the course, or have us develop workshops with unique policy use cases, do not hesitate to contact us!
